block.p: For the 60th anniversary of the opening of Franklin D. Roosevelt's home in Hyde Park, N.Y., to the public, and also of the founding of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, the institute's American Bounty restaurant is serving Roosevelt's favorite dishes at lunch and dinner through July 6: (845) 471-6608.

Today, the three Whole Foods markets in Manhattan will donate 5 percent of every purchase to the Council on the Environment of New York City for the renovation of the Miracle Garden, a community garden at 194-196 East Third Street. The money will go to benches, paths, plants, tree pruning and fencing.
A panel discussion about sustainable agriculture in the New York region will be held this evening from 6 to 8 at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, room 510. Admission is free.
You can sample cuts of beef with red wines tonight from 6 to 9 at Gallagher's Steak House, 228 West 52nd Street, for $85: (212) 956-4328.
Food shops and restaurants in the World Financial Center will offer tastes ($2 to $5) on Friday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. in the Winter Garden.

A series of tastings at Chanterelle, 2 Harrison Street (Hudson Street), will begin this Sunday from 4 to 6 p.m. with pairings of cheeses with sparkling and white wines, $55. To reserve, call Amy Ehrenreich: (212) 966-6960.
A beer tasting dinner will be held on Monday from 6 to 9 p.m. at HQ, 90 Thompson Street (Spring Street). The cost is $40: (212) 966-2755.

Guided tastings of single barrel and limited edition bourbons on Tuesday, single malt Scotch on May 23, and American pinot noirs on June 20 will be held at Keen's Steakhouse, 72 West 36th Street. All tastings begin at 7 p.m. They are $65 each or $175 for all three: (212) 947-3636.

A six-course dinner paired with some prized California wines, including Araujo, William Selyem, Peter Michael and Turley, will be held on Tuesday at Stone Park Cafe, 324 Fifth Avenue (Third Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn. The cost is $185, plus tax and tip: (718) 369-0082.

Georges Pralus, an expert on the sous vide technique, in which food is vacuum-wrapped and slowly heated, will participate in a seminar on April 26 and 27 from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. in the David Bouley test kitchen, 88 West Broadway (Chambers Street). There will be demonstrations, with an emphasis on required safety measures. The cost is $375 a person including lunch: (212) 964-2525.

A tasting of dishes from dozens of Queens restaurants and samples from food and drink purveyors will be held by the Queens Economic Development Corporation on April 26 from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. at Douglaston Manor, 62-20 Commonwealth Boulevard in Douglaston. Those attending will be able to vote on the best in several categories. Tickets are $60: (718) 263-0546.
